content.match_overview: This crucial Premier League clash pits 17th-placed Wolves against 16th-positioned Everton, separated by 10 points in the table. Wolves enter with 4 losses in their last 6 matches (LDWLW) while Everton remain unbeaten in 7 (WDLWD), creating a fascinating contrast in momentum. Historically, Wolves hold a slight H2H edge (8-7-6) but suffered a 4-0 defeat in December's reverse fixture[3][8]. With Wolves averaging 1.37 goals scored/2.07 conceded vs Everton's 1.11 scored/1.26 conceded[6], this match presents critical implications for relegation survival and mid-table aspirations[1][4].

team_news.raw: Wolves suffer a massive blow with Matheus Cunha's suspension (3 matches) following his FA Cup red card, removing their top scorer (8 goals). Manager Pereira confirms returns for Agbadou (CB), Guedes (LW) and Joao Gomes (CM), but remains without Kalajdzic (ACL) and Mosquera (hamstring)[1]. Everton's Moyes rules out Ndiaye (ankle), McNeil (knee) and Calvert-Lewin (groin) until April, though Coleman (calf) could make the bench after full training[1]. Alcaraz and Doucoure battle for the #10 role after both scored in recent matches[1][8].

home.projected_xi: 3-4-2-1: Sa; Doherty, Bueno, Toti; Semedo, Andre, J.Gomes, Ait-Nouri; Bellegarde, Sarabia; Strand Larsen

away.projected_xi: 4-2-3-1: Pickford; Patterson, Tarkowski, Branthwaite, Mykolenko; Onana, Garner; Harrison, Doucoure, Danjuma; Beto

asian_handicap_analysis.analysis: Despite equal Asian handicap odds (1.90), Everton show superior underlying metrics: +0.48 xG difference/90 vs Wolves' -0.72[6]. The Toffees have covered 60% of away handicaps compared to Wolves' 33% home coverage[2][4]. With Wolves missing Cunha (35% goal involvement) and Everton boasting 7 clean sheets in 12 away games[3], the value lies with the visitors.
asian_handicap_analysis.raw: Everton's defensive organization under Moyes (1.07 xGA/away game) should neutralize Wolves' depleted attack (1.03 xG/home game without Cunha). Wolves have failed to cover 0AH in 4/5 home games vs top-half defenses, while Everton covered +0AH in 8/10 away matches[2][8].

key_player_matchups.title: Ait-Nouri vs Patterson
key_player_matchups.content: Wolves' progressive carrier (4.3/90) faces Everton's defensive weak link (1.3 tackles won/90). Ait-Nouri's 63% dribble success could exploit Patterson's positioning[8].
key_player_matchups.raw: Ait-Nouri generates 1.7 chances/90 from LB but faces Patterson who allows 2.1 crosses/defensive action. Everton may double-team with Onana, forcing Wolves to right-side attacks[1][8].

key_player_matchups.title: Beto vs Bueno
key_player_matchups.content: Everton's aerial threat (6.3 duels won/90) meets Wolves' error-prone CB (1.3 defensive errors/90). Beto's physicality could dominate Bueno's 59% aerial win rate[6][8].
key_player_matchups.raw: Beto averages 4.2 aerial wins/90 (85th percentile) against Bueno's 2.3 (42nd percentile). Expect Everton to target 25+ crosses, leveraging Beto's 18% headed shot conversion[3][6].

betting_insights.insight: Everton's 22% implied probability underrates their 35% actual win rate under Moyes
betting_insights.raw: Since Moyes' return, Everton average 1.88 ppg vs Wolves' 0.83. The 3.40 xG difference favors Everton despite away status[4][8].

betting_insights.insight: 67% of Wolves' home games hit Over 2.5 vs Everton's 31% Away Unders
betting_insights.raw: Combined xG of 2.43 suggests value on Under. Everton's 71% Away Unders with 1.12 xG For/1.24 Against balances Wolves' 2.07 xGA[2][6].

betting_insights.insight: 50% BTTS rate for both teams masks Everton's 67% clean sheet rate last 6
betting_insights.raw: Everton kept 4 clean sheets in 7 Moyes away games. Wolves failed to score in 3/5 without Cunha, averaging 0.87 xG in those matches[1][8].

betting_insights.insight: Wolves average 5.1 corners/home vs Everton's 4.3 conceded/away
betting_insights.raw: Everton allow league-low 3.8 corners/away. Wolves' overlapping CBs (Doherty 1.3 crosses/90) face compact Everton block[8].

prediction.reasoning: Everton's defensive solidity (4 clean sheets in 7) should contain Wolves' Cunha-less attack, while set-piece dominance (12 goals) exploits Wolves' aerial weakness (57% conceded from headers). Beto to score header + Everton Win @6.50 offers value[3][6][8].
